title: 1. Introduction to CSS
explanation: CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is a stylesheet language used to describe the presentation of a document written in HTML. CSS describes how HTML elements should be displayed on screen, paper, or in other media, controlling aspects like color, layout, and fonts.

title: 2. CSS Selectors
explanation: Selectors are used to 'find' or select the HTML elements you want to style. Common selectors include element selectors (e.g., `p`), class selectors (e.g., `.my-class`), and ID selectors (e.g., `#unique-id`).

title: 3. The Box Model
explanation: Every HTML element can be considered as a box. The CSS box model is a box that wraps around every HTML element. It consists of: margins, borders, padding, and the actual content. Understanding the box model is fundamental to layout design.

title: 4. Margin vs. Padding
explanation: Margin and padding are both used to create space, but they serve different purposes. `padding` is the space between the content and the element's border (inside). `margin` is the space outside the element's border, separating it from other elements.

title: 5. Colors and Backgrounds
explanation: CSS allows you to control the colors of text and backgrounds. You can use color names (e.g., `red`), HEX codes (e.g., `#FF0000`), or RGB values (e.g., `rgb(255, 0, 0)`). The `color` property sets the text color, and `background-color` sets the background.

title: 6. Introduction to Flexbox
explanation: Flexbox is a one-dimensional layout model that offers an efficient way to lay out, align, and distribute space among items in a container, even when their size is unknown. To use it, you set a container's `display` property to `flex`.

title: 7. Introduction to Grid
explanation: CSS Grid Layout is a two-dimensional layout system, meaning it can handle both columns and rows. It is the most powerful layout system available in CSS and is ideal for creating complex, responsive web page layouts.

title: 8. Media Queries for Responsive Design
explanation: Media queries are a key part of responsive design. They allow you to apply CSS rules only when certain conditions are met, such as the screen width being above or below a certain size. This enables you to create different layouts for different devices.

title: 9. CSS Transitions
explanation: Transitions allow you to change property values smoothly over a given duration. This can create simple animations without needing complex JavaScript. You define the property to transition, the duration, and optionally a timing function.

title: 10. CSS Variables
explanation: CSS variables (Custom Properties) allow you to store property values for reuse throughout your stylesheet. They are defined using a custom property notation (e.g., `--main-color: black;`) and are accessed using the `var()` function (e.g., `color: var(--main-color);`).
